hypotheses.title: Active Exploitation of BeyondTrust RCE (CVE-2026-1731) for Ransomware Deployment
hypotheses.description: Threat actors are actively exploiting a critical RCE vulnerability (CVE-2026-1731) in BeyondTrust Remote Support and Privileged Remote Access products to deploy VShell and SparkRAT, leading to ransomware attacks. This vulnerability allows unauthenticated remote code execution, making it a high-priority target for immediate hunting.
mitre_attack_techniques: T1059.001 - Command and Scripting Interpreter: PowerShell
T1574 - Boot or Logon Autostart Execution

data_sources_needed.specific_data: Process creation logs, specifically looking for VShell, SparkRAT, or unexpected PowerShell execution from BeyondTrust services.
Outbound connections from BeyondTrust servers to unknown C2 domains or IPs, specifically DNS queries for VShell.
Cloud audit logs for BeyondTrust instances showing unauthorized configuration changes or new user creation.

hunting_tactics.description: Search for processes spawned by BeyondTrust services that are not standard binaries, specifically VShell or SparkRAT.
sample_queries: Splunk: index=endpoint_process_creation ParentProcessName="beyondtrust*" ProcessName IN ("vshell", "sparkrat", "powershell", "cmd") | table _time, host, ProcessName, CommandLine

KQL (Sentinel): DeviceProcessEvents | where ParentProcessName contains "BeyondTrust" and ProcessName in ("vshell.exe", "sparkrat.exe", "powershell.exe") | project TimeGenerated, DeviceName, ProcessName, CommandLine
hunting_tactics.look_for: Execution of 'vshell.exe', 'sparkrat.exe', or PowerShell commands initiated by BeyondTrust service accounts.

hunting_tactics.description: Identify outbound connections from BeyondTrust servers to suspicious external IPs or domains that do not match known vendor infrastructure.
sample_queries: Splunk: index=network src_ip IN (SELECT ip FROM asset_inventory WHERE software_name="BeyondTrust") AND dest_ip NOT IN (SELECT ip FROM allowlist) | stats count by src_ip, dest_ip, dest_port

KQL: NetworkTraffic | where SourceDeviceName contains "BeyondTrust" and DestinationIsExternal == true and DestinationIP notin (list_of_known_vendor_ips) | summarize count() by DestinationIP, DestinationPort
hunting_tactics.look_for: Unusual outbound traffic from management servers, particularly on non-standard ports or to newly registered domains.

network_patterns: DNS TXT record queries for C2

recommended_actions: Immediately isolate affected BeyondTrust servers from the network.
Patch all BeyondTrust instances to the latest version addressing CVE-2026-1731.
Reset credentials for all administrative accounts associated with BeyondTrust.
Scan endpoints for VShell and SparkRAT artifacts.

hypotheses.title: ClickFix DNS Tunneling Variant Using nslookup for Malware Staging
hypotheses.description: The ClickFix campaign has evolved to use the 'nslookup' command to retrieve malware payloads via DNS responses, bypassing traditional command-line blocking. Attackers trick users into running a DNS lookup command that parses the response to fetch the next-stage payload (e.g., ModeloRAT).
mitre_attack_techniques: T1059.001 - Command and Scripting Interpreter: PowerShell

data_sources_needed.specific_data: Command line arguments for 'nslookup' containing suspicious domains or parsing logic.
DNS queries for TXT records or unusual DNS response sizes that might contain encoded payloads.
Phishing emails containing instructions to run 'nslookup' commands or fake CAPTCHA pages.

hunting_tactics.description: Hunt for 'nslookup' commands executed with specific domains or arguments that suggest payload retrieval rather than standard DNS resolution.
sample_queries: Splunk: index=endpoint_process_creation ProcessName="nslookup.exe" AND CommandLine NOT LIKE "%localhost%" AND CommandLine NOT LIKE "%google.com%" | table _time, host, CommandLine
KQL: DeviceProcessEvents | where ProcessName == "nslookup.exe" and CommandLine !contains "localhost" and CommandLine !contains "google.com" | project TimeGenerated, DeviceName, CommandLine
hunting_tactics.look_for: nslookup commands targeting non-standard domains, especially those with long subdomains or specific TLDs used in the campaign.

hunting_tactics.description: Analyze DNS logs for TXT record queries that return unusually large responses or contain base64-encoded data.
sample_queries: Splunk: index=dns query_type="TXT" AND response_size > 100 | stats count by query_name, response_size
KQL: DnsEvents | where QueryType == "TXT" and ResponseSize > 100 | summarize count() by QueryName, ResponseSize
hunting_tactics.look_for: TXT record responses containing base64 strings or executable code fragments.

network_patterns: DNS TXT queries with large responses
other_indicators: Fake CAPTCHA pages in email attachments

recommended_actions: Block execution of 'nslookup' from user contexts if not required for business operations.
Implement DNS filtering to block TXT record queries to suspicious domains.
Educate users on the risks of running commands from phishing emails.
Scan for ModeloRAT artifacts on endpoints.

hypotheses.title: Supply Chain Compromise via Malicious NPM/PyPI Packages (Lazarus & SmartLoader)
hypotheses.description: Threat actors like Lazarus Group and SmartLoader are distributing malicious npm and PyPI packages disguised as legitimate tools (e.g., Oura MCP server, fake recruiter packages). These packages steal credentials, deploy infostealers (StealC), and compromise developer environments.
mitre_attack_techniques: T1195.002 - Supply Chain Compromise: Compromise Software Supply Chain
T1059.007 - Command and Scripting Interpreter: Python

data_sources_needed.specific_data: Installation logs for npm/PyPI packages, specifically looking for packages with names similar to legitimate ones but different authors or versions.
Outbound connections from developer machines to known malicious C2 domains associated with StealC or Oura MCP clones.
CI/CD pipeline logs showing installation of suspicious packages or unusual dependency updates.

hunting_tactics.description: Identify installations of npm/PyPI packages that match known malicious package names or authors.
sample_queries: Splunk: index=ci_cd_logs action="install" AND package_name IN ("graphalgo", "oura-mcp-server", "stripeapi.net") | table _time, user, package_name, version
KQL: PackageInstallEvents | where PackageName in ("graphalgo", "oura-mcp-server", "stripeapi.net") | project TimeGenerated, User, PackageName, Version

hunting_tactics.description: Detect outbound connections from developer environments to StealC or other infostealer C2 infrastructure.
sample_queries: Splunk: index=network src_ip IN (SELECT ip FROM developer_hosts) AND dest_ip IN (SELECT ip FROM stealc_iocs) | table _time, src_ip, dest_ip
KQL: NetworkTraffic | where SourceDeviceName in (list_of_dev_machines) and DestinationIP in (list_of_stealc_ips) | summarize count() by DestinationIP
hunting_tactics.look_for: Connections to known StealC C2 IPs or domains from developer workstations.

network_patterns: npm install commands for suspicious packages
other_indicators: Malicious npm packages with typosquatting names

recommended_actions: Audit all npm and PyPI dependencies in CI/CD pipelines for known malicious packages.
Block network access to known StealC C2 infrastructure.
Implement strict package signing and verification in development environments.
Scan developer machines for StealC artifacts.

hypotheses.title: AI Agent Compromise: OpenClaw Configuration Theft and C2 Abuse
hypotheses.description: Infostealers are now targeting OpenClaw AI agent configurations, stealing API keys, authentication tokens, and 'digital souls' of personal AI agents. Additionally, AI agents like Copilot and Grok are being abused as C2 proxies to relay commands and evade detection.
mitre_attack_techniques: T1567.002 - Exfiltration Over Web Service: Web Service
T1071.001 - Application Layer Protocol: Web Protocols

data_sources_needed.specific_data: File access logs for OpenClaw configuration directories and API key files.
Outbound connections from AI agent processes to suspicious C2 domains or AI service endpoints.
API usage logs for AI services showing unusual patterns or unauthorized access.

hunting_tactics.description: Monitor for unauthorized access or exfiltration of OpenClaw configuration files and API keys.
sample_queries: Splunk: index=endpoint_file_access path="*openclaw*" AND action="read" AND user NOT IN ("admin", "developer") | table _time, host, user, path
KQL: FileEvents | where FileName contains "openclaw" and Operation == "Read" and AccountName notin ("admin", "developer") | project TimeGenerated, Computer, AccountName, FileName
hunting_tactics.look_for: Access to OpenClaw config files by non-authorized users or processes.

hunting_tactics.description: Identify AI agent processes (Copilot, Grok) making unexpected outbound connections or relaying data to external IPs.
sample_queries: Splunk: index=network ProcessName IN ("copilot.exe", "grok.exe") AND dest_ip NOT IN (SELECT ip FROM allowlist) | table _time, host, dest_ip
KQL: NetworkTraffic | where ProcessName in ("copilot.exe", "grok.exe") and DestinationIsExternal == true | summarize count() by DestinationIP
hunting_tactics.look_for: AI agent processes connecting to non-standard external IPs or domains.

network_patterns: Outbound HTTPS from AI agents to unknown IPs
DNS queries for AI C2 domains

recommended_actions: Restrict access to OpenClaw configuration files and API keys.
Monitor AI agent processes for unusual network activity.
Implement network segmentation for AI agent traffic.
Audit AI service API usage for anomalies.

hypotheses.title: ShinyHunters Extortion Campaign: Data Exfiltration and Leak Site Monitoring
hypotheses.description: ShinyHunters is actively targeting organizations (e.g., Odido, CarGurus, Wynn Resorts) with data breaches, exfiltrating millions of records and threatening to leak them unless ransoms are paid. Hunting should focus on detecting data exfiltration patterns and monitoring leak sites for organizational data.
mitre_attack_techniques: T1567.002 - Exfiltration Over Web Service: Web Service

data_sources_needed.specific_data: Large file transfers or data access patterns indicating bulk data exfiltration.
Outbound data transfers to ShinyHunters-associated domains or IPs.
Cloud storage access logs showing unusual data downloads or sharing.

hunting_tactics.description: Identify large volumes of data being accessed or transferred, particularly from sensitive directories.
sample_queries: Splunk: index=endpoint_file_access path="*customer*" AND bytes_read > 100000000 | stats sum(bytes_read) by host, user
KQL: FileEvents | where FileName contains "customer" and BytesRead > 100000000 | summarize total_bytes = sum(BytesRead) by Computer, AccountName
hunting_tactics.look_for: Large file reads or transfers from customer data directories.

hunting_tactics.description: Monitor ShinyHunters leak sites and dark web forums for mentions of the organization or leaked data samples.
sample_queries: Splunk: index=threat_intel source="shinyhunters_leak_site" AND organization_name="*" | table _time, organization_name, data_sample
KQL: ThreatIntel | where Source == "ShinyHunters" and OrganizationName contains "*" | project TimeGenerated, OrganizationName, DataSample
hunting_tactics.look_for: Mentions of the organization on ShinyHunters leak site or dark web forums.

recommended_actions: Monitor ShinyHunters leak sites and dark web forums for organizational data.
Implement DLP controls to prevent bulk data exfiltration.
Review access logs for sensitive data directories.
Prepare incident response plan for potential data breach.

unique_mitre_techniques: T1574 - Boot or Logon Autostart Execution
T1567.002 - Exfiltration Over Web Service: Web Service
T1195.002 - Supply Chain Compromise: Compromise Software Supply Chain
T1059.007 - Command and Scripting Interpreter: Python
